questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) due to infertility. The embryologist informs her that the fertilized egg has reached a stage where it resembles a solid ball of cells. What is the term for this developmental stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morula

 

Option C: The morula is a developmental stage in embryogenesis characterized by a solid ball of cells formed from the cleavage divisions of the zygote, occurring just before the formation of the blastocyst.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The blastocyst stage occurs after the morula stage. It is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (blastocoel) within the developing embryo and consists of an inner cell mass (which will give rise to the fetus) and an outer layer of cells (trophoblast).

 

Option B: The zygote is the initial cell formed when sperm fertilizes an egg. It is the earliest stage of embryonic development and undergoes several cleavage divisions to form the morula.

 

Option D: Blastomeres are individual cells that make up the morula. During cleavage divisions, the zygote divides into blastomeres, which then compact together to form the morula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The morula is a solid ball of cells resulting from multiple cleavage divisions of the zygote. It typically consists of 12-32 cells and is the stage just before the blastocyst.

 

Ref: Larsen’s Human Embryology, 6th Edition, Page no- 34-35

questions.text: Muscle derived from First Pharyngeal Arch:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mylohyoid

 

Option C:

 

  • Nerve of the first pharyngeal arch is Mandibular nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The buccinator muscle is derived from the second pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by facial nerve.

 

Option B: The stylopharyngeus muscle is derived from the third pharyngeal arch, not the first. This muscle is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which is associated with the third arch.

 

Option D: The hyoglossus muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. Hyoglossus muscle is innervated by Hypoglossal Nerve and is derived from Occipital somites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mylohyoid muscle is indeed derived from the first pharyngeal arch.
  • It forms the floor of the oral cavity and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. The first pharyngeal arch is primarily associated with the trigeminal nerve.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 97.

questions.text: All the following occur as a result of Conotruncal Septum anomalies except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VSD

 

Option A:

 

  • Conotruncal septum forms the spiral septum which divides the outflow tract into aorta and pulmonary trunk and has no role in formation of interventricular septum.
  • Ventricular septal defects can involve membranous or muscular component of interventricular septum.
  • Anomalies in the conotruncal septum can lead to several congenital heart defects.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Persistent Truncus Arteriosus (PTA) occurs when the conotruncal septum fails to develop properly, resulting in a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart, instead of separate pulmonary and aortic trunks. This is a direct result of a conotruncal septum anomaly.

 

Option C: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) is a condition where the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched. This is due to abnormal development of the conotruncal septum, which fails to align properly with the ventricular septum.

 

Option D: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a complex heart defect that includes four abnormalities: VSD, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The overriding aorta, which is a key feature of TOF, occurs due to an anterior deviation of the conotruncal septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is a defect in the ventricular septum, the wall dividing the left and right ventricles of the heart.
  • While it is a common congenital heart defect, it is not result of conotruncal septum anomalies.
  • VSDs are usually related to defects in the formation of the interventricular septum rather than the conotruncal septum.

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 180

questions.text: Fertilization is complete when:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2nd Polar Body is formed

 

Option B:

 

  • Polar body formed as a result of completion of Second Meiotic Division

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The formation of the first polar body occurs as a part of oogenesis, specifically during the first meiotic division. Primary oocyte completes first meiotic division and forms secondary oocyte and first polar body in the ovary during follicular phase.

 

Option C: The formation of the primary oocyte is an early stage in oogenesis and occurs before the oocyte is released from the ovary. The primary oocyte is arrested in prophase I of meiosis until ovulation. The formation of the primary oocyte is not related to the completion of fertilization.

 

Option D: The secondary oocyte is formed after the first meiotic division and is the cell that is ovulated and available for fertilization. However, the formation of the secondary oocyte is not the final step in fertilization. The secondary oocyte remains arrested in metaphase II of meiosis until fertilization occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fertilization is complete when the second polar body is formed.
  • This event occurs after the sperm has penetrated the oocyte, and the oocyte completes its second meiotic division.
  • The formation of the second polar body ensures that the resulting zygote has the correct haploid number of chromosomes from the female gamete.

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 12

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is seen in the fertility clinic due to difficulty conceiving for the past two years. During her evaluation, the physician discusses various aspects of reproductive biology. She explains the origin of germ cells, which are crucial for fertility. From which of the following embryonic structures are germ cells derived?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epiblast
 

Option A:

 

Primordial germ cells give rise to sperm in males and ovum in females and are derived from epiblast

 

 

  • In the context of reproductive health and fertility, understanding the origin of germ cells is important.
  • Germ cells, which give rise to gametes (sperms and ova), are derived from the epiblast, an embryonic structure.
  • The epiblast cells migrate to the primitive streak and then to the gonadal ridges, where they differentiate into gametes.
  • This embryological process is crucial for normal fertility, and abnormalities in germ cell development can lead to fertility issues, as may be relevant in this patient's case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The hypoblast is a layer of cells in the early embryo that contributes to the formation of the extraembryonic structures like the yolk sac. However, it does not give rise to germ cells. The hypoblast is located beneath the epiblast but is not involved in the formation of the primary germ layers or the germ cells.

 

Option C: The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers formed during gastrulation. It gives rise to the lining of the digestive and respiratory systems and associated organs. While the endoderm is important for many aspects of organogenesis, it is not the source of germ cells.

 

Option D: Neural crest cells are a group of cells that originate from the ectoderm and contribute to the development of many structures, including certain neurons, glial cells, and components of the peripheral nervous system. However, they are not involved in the formation of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Germ cells are derived from the epiblast, which is a layer of cells in the early embryo.
  • The epiblast gives rise to all three primary germs during gastrulation and also to the primordial germ cells. These primordial germ cells migrate to the developing gonads where they will eventually give rise to gametes.

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 6

choices.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

 

Option B:

 

  • The “Plate” is the Hyaline Cartilage between the Shaft (Diaphysis) and End (Epiphysis) of a Long bone in Children and Adolescents.
  • The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.
  • In Adults it is replaced by an ossified “Epiphyseal Line”.

 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone. The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity.

 

Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone.  While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis, it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation.

 

Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal, or medullary cavity, is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the knee joint. Physical examination reveals warmth and tenderness around the affected joint, and imaging studies show joint space narrowing and bone erosion. Which of the following category of joint is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Freely Moveable Joint

 

Option C.

 

  • Knee joint is the type of diarthosis or synovial joint which is the example of freely moveable joint.
  • Synovial fluid is present in between articular surfaces.
  • In this case knee joint is involved which is classical example of synovial joint.
  • Synovial joints are filled with synovial fluid which is the lubricant that allows friction free joint movement.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):

 

  • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement.
  • An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull.
  • Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints, as they allow no movement.

 

Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:

 

  • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis.
  • It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage.
  • An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine.
  • While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement, they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freely Moveable Joint:

 

  • It allows a wide range of movement. Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow.
  • They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid, which facilitates movement.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 88

questions.text: Which of the following lists comprises bones that are part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clavicle, Fibula,  Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius

 

Option B.

 

  • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular system)
  • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular system)
  • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular system)
  • This list contains bones from appendicular skeletons only, hence it is answer.
  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial skeleton
    • Appendicular skeleton
  • All bones of axial & appendicular system are shown in below image

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia

 

  • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum

 

  • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Scapula (Shoulder Blade) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Occipital is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Metacarpals are the bones in the hand, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Sternum (Breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal

 

  • Ulna is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalanges are the finger and toe bones, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Mandible (Lower Jawbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Coxal (Hip Bone) is part of the pelvic girdle of the appendicular skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial Skeleton
    • Appendicular Skeleton
      • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular System)
      • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular System)
      • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular System)

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 66

questions.text: In the context of young bones, which part is primarily responsible for longitudinal growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate

 

It is present between metaphysis and epiphysis in the growing bone. Once the complete fusion of this plate takes place the growth also stops.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diaphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis.
  • It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.

 

Option B. Epiphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis.
  • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability, it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.

 

Option C. Metaphysis 

 

  • Metaphysis is the part of the bone between diaphysis and growth plate in the growing bone and in the adult bone it lies between diaphysis and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

questions.text: Which of the following bone of the skull articulates to form a synovial joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Mandible

 

Option C:

 

  • The Ramus of the mandible articulates with the temporal bone at the mandibular fossa.
  • The joint is freely moveable, allowing us to chew and speak.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Sphenoid

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, forming part of the cranial floor.
  • It does not form a synovial joint; rather, it articulates with other cranial bones through sutures.

 

Option B. The Maxilla

 

  • It forms the upper jaw and is involved in forming the roof of the mouth, floors of the orbits, and sides and floor of the nasal cavity.
  • The maxilla is fused to other bones of the face and does not form a synovial joint.

 

Option D. The Hyoid

 

  • It is a U-shaped bone in the neck that supports the tongue and provides attachment for muscles associated with swallowing.
  • It is not directly attached to other bones but is suspended by ligaments and muscles.
  • The hyoid does not form a synovial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mandible or lower jawbone, forms a synovial joint with the temporal bone of the skull known as the Temporo-Mandibular Joint (TMJ). It is a bicondylar type of synovial joint that allows for the movement necessary for chewing, speaking, and other mouth movements.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy regional and clinical head, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 17

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case knee cap bone Patella is involved, which is classical example of sesamoid bone.
  • Important Features of Sesamoid bone.

 

  1. Small and Ossified: Sesamoid bones are typically small, flat, and rounded bones that develop within tendons. They are typically composed of ossified (hardened) tissue.
  2. Location: They are commonly found near joints, especially in areas subject to significant mechanical stress, such as the hands, feet, and knees.
  3. Function: Sesamoid bones serve as pulleys, reducing friction and providing leverage for tendons as they pass over joints. They help improve joint function and protect tendons from excessive wear and tear.
  4. They ossify after the birth.
  5. These bones are having –
    • No Haversian canal.
    • No medullary cavity.
    • No periosteusm.

 

Examples of Sesamoid Bones in Body:

 

  1. Patella (Kneecap):

 

  • The largest sesamoid bone in the human body is the patella, which is located in the front of the knee joint.
  • It is ossified in tendon of quadriceps femoris.

 

  1. Pisiform:

 

  • It ossifies within tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • It is the last carpal bone to ossify.

 

  1. Fabella:
  • It is found in lateral head of gastrocnemius muscle.

 

  1. At Thumb (First Metacarpal):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are often present at the base of the thumb (first metacarpal bone), where they contribute to the flexibility and strength of thumb movements.

 

  1. At Foot (Metatarsophalangeal Joints):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are commonly found beneath the metatarsophalangeal joints of the foot, especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint near the big toe.
  • They assist in weight-bearing and movement of the foot during activities like walking and running.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Understanding the presence and function of sesamoid bones is essential for healthcare professionals, as injuries or conditions related to these bones can impact joint mobility, stability, and overall musculoskeletal health.
  • X-ray Identification: Sesamoid bones are often visible on X-rays, and their presence and location can be important for diagnosing certain medical conditions, such as fractures or inflammation related to sesamoid bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sphenoid –

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, in the middle of the cranial floor.
  • It is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option B. Hyoid –

 

  • U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck that does not directly articulate with any other bone.
  • It serves as an anchoring structure for the tongue and muscles in the neck and throat but is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option C. Ethmoid –

 

  • It is located between the eyes and at the roof of the nasal cavity.
  • It is part of the cranial floor and contributes to the medial wall of the orbit, the nasal septum, and the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sesamoid: Sesamoid bones like patella are small, round bones that are embedded within tendons. They are found in locations where a tendon passes over a joint, such as the knee, hand, and foot. It helps to overcome compressive forces and modify pressure, reduce friction, and occasionally alter the direction of muscle pull.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

choices.text: The Flexing of the arm with respect to the Forearm around the Elbow.
The Swivelling of the foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions.
The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.
The Rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a Cone Shape.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.

 

Option C:

 

  • Supination: Upward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).
  • Pronation: Downward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Flexing of the Arm with Respect to the Forearm around the Elbow: This describes flexion and extension, not pronation or supination. Flexion refers to decreasing the angle between the forearm and arm, while extension is increasing this angle.

 

 

Option B. The Swivelling of the Foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions: This is describing inversion and eversion of the foot. Inversion involves turning the sole of the foot inward, while eversion is turning it outward. These movements occur at the ankle and subtalar joints.

 

 

Option D. The Rotation at the Shoulder that Causes the Arm to Describe a Cone Shape: This is describing circumduction, a circular movement of the limb that combines flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. It is not specific to pronation or supination.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Twisting of the Wrist While the Elbow is Held Motionless: This correctly describes pronation and supination. These movements occur primarily at the radioulnar joint. In pronation, the radius rotates over the ulna so the palm faces downward. In supination, the radius and ulna are parallel, and the palm faces upward.

 

Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 134

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department after a fall. Imaging studies are ordered to assess for spinal injury. Compared to an adult, at which vertebral level does the spinal cord typically end in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. L3-L4 Inter-Vertebral Disc

 

Option C:

 

  • In infants, the spinal cord extends further down the vertebral column and typically ends around the L3-L4 intervertebral disc. This is important to consider during procedures such as a lumbar puncture to avoid injury to the spinal cord.
  • The L3-L4 intervertebral disc is a common site for lumbar puncture in adults; however, in infants, the spinal cord extends to this level, making this an incorrect choice for a lumbar puncture site in infants.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. In adults, the spinal cord usually ends at the level of the L1-L2 intervertebral disc. This is the typical location for the conus medullaris in an adult patient.

 

Option B: L2-L3 Inter-Vertebral Disc is above the level of termination of spinal cord in infants whereas in adults spinal cord terminates above this level.

 

Option D. The T12-L1 intervertebral disc level is above the terminal end of the spinal cord even in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that the spinal cord in infants typically ends around the L2-L3 intervertebral disc, which is lower than in adults, where it ends at the L1-L2 intervertebral disc level. This knowledge is crucial when performing procedures like lumbar punctures in infants to avoid iatrogenic injury to the spinal cord.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 51-52.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with numbness and a loss of vibratory sense and proprioception in both lower extremities. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch in a stocking distribution, absent Achilles tendon reflex, and a positive Romberg sign. These findings suggest a lesion affecting which of the following neural pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dorsal Columns (Posterior Columns)

 

Option C:

 

  • The dorsal columns (posterior columns) of the spinal cord carry information about touch, vibratory sense, and proprioception. Diabetes can cause peripheral neuropathy, which may lead to a loss of these sensations, typically starting in the lower extremities.
  • The presence of a positive Romberg sign is indicative of proprioceptive loss, which aligns with dorsal column dysfunction.

 

Explanation:


Option A. The lateral corticospinal tract is responsible for voluntary motor control. A lesion here would likely result in spastic paralysis and hyperreflexia, not sensory deficits.

 

Option B. The anterolateral (spinothalamic) tract carries pain and temperature sensations. While damage to this tract can cause loss of pain and temperature sensation, it does not affect vibratory sense or proprioception.

 

Option D. The lateral spinothalamic tract specifically carries pain and temperature sensations from the body to the brain. As with the anterolateral tract, a lesion here would not affect vibratory sense or proprioception.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Loss of proprioception and vibratory sense, along with a positive Romberg sign, is indicative of a lesion in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, which are responsible for carrying proprioceptive and fine touch information from the periphery to the brain.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 60-65.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. Imaging studies reveal a hemorrhagic stroke within the left basal ganglia. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved in supplying the area of the patient's stroke in the putamen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Middle Cerebral Artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) supplies a significant portion of the basal ganglia, including the putamen.
  • Lenticulostriate arteries, which are small penetrating branches of the MCA, specifically provide blood to the putamen and are often implicated in hypertensive hemorrhagic strokes in this region.

 

Explanation:


Option B. The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) primarily supplies the medial surfaces of the frontal lobes and superior medial parietal lobes. It does not typically supply the basal ganglia.

 

Option C. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) mainly supplies the occipital lobe and the bottom portion of the temporal lobe. It does not provide the primary blood supply to the basal ganglia.

 

Option D. The anterior choroidal artery can contribute to the blood supply of the posterior limb of the internal capsule and part of the basal ganglia, but it is less commonly involved in hypertensive hemorrhages affecting the putamen compared to the lenticulostriate branches of the MCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle cerebral artery, through its lenticulostriate branches, is the primary supplier of blood to the putamen, and hemorrhagic strokes in this area are often related to hypertension-induced damage to these small penetrating vessels.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 172.

questions.text: All of the following muscles have dual nerve supply except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pronator Teres

 

Option C:

 

  • Any muscle with double nerve supply known as Hybrid / Composite muscle
  • Pronator teres is innervated by the median nerve only.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option B. Pectoralis major is innervated by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves.

 

Option D. FDP tendon for medial ½ is innervated by the ulnar nerve and FDP tendon lateral ½ is  innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pronator teres muscle, helps to pronate the forearm and receives its nerve supply from the median nerve.
  • The median nerve originates from the brachial plexus, specifically from the lateral and medial cords and travels down the arm and into the forearm, it innervates several muscles, including the pronator teres.

 

Hybrid muscles of Upper Limb:

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram singh, pg. 101

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a concern about a "visible vein" in his right shoulder area. He reports that the vein becomes more pronounced during exercise or when lifting heavy objects. There is no associated pain, redness, or swelling. He denies any history of trauma to the area. On inspection of the right shoulder area reveals a prominent, non-pulsatile, linear structure running along the deltopectoral groove is seen. Which of the following structure is seen in this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cephalic Vein

 

Option B:

 

  • The deltopectoral groove, also known as the infraclavicular fossa/ deltopectoral triangle.
  • It is a significant anatomical feature located between the deltoid and pectoral muscles. 
  • Deltopectoral groove lodges cephalic vein and deltoid branch of thoracoacromial artery.

 

 

  • Coracoid process is palpable in this groove.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Axillary Artery supplies blood to the upper limb and runs through the axilla. 
  • While the axillary artery is in the vicinity, it is not specifically related to the deltopectoral groove.
  • The artery is deeper and more medially located compared to this groove.

 

Option C.

 

  • Basilic Vein is another superficial vein of the upper limb, located more medially compared to the cephalic vein.
  • The basilic vein does not run through the deltopectoral groove.
  • It is situated on the medial side of the arm and does not have a direct anatomical relationship with this groove.

 

Option D.

 

  • Radial Nerve is one of the major nerves of the upper limb, involved in the motor and sensory innervation of the arm and hand.
  • The radial nerve does not pass through the deltopectoral groove.
  • It travels along the posterior compartment of the arm and is more related to the triceps muscle and the radial groove of the humerus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cephalic vein is a superficial vein of the upper limb.
  • It runs along the preaxial border of the upper limb.
  • It passes through the deltopectoral groove.
  • It is a significant landmark for certain surgical procedures, running between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles before it drains into the axillary vein.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 33

choices.text: Loss of Sensation on Lower Lateral Aspect of Arm
Weak of Flexion of Arm at Shoulder Joint
Inability to Extend the Arm at Shoulder Joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. Pain was sudden at onset, continuous, and moderate to severe in intensity and it was aggravated on activity. In addition, he had severe night and rest pain. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. MRI scan of the right shoulder showed pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with central abscess formation. Which among the following is not a possible complication that can be expected in this case if untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of Sensation on Lower Lateral Aspect of Arm

 

Option A:

 

  • The case describes a patient with pyomyositis of the deltoid muscle, which is a bacterial infection leading to abscess formation within the muscle.
  • In this case, the intramuscular injection injured the axillary nerve supply to the deltoid muscle.
  • Axillary nerve gives rise to upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm, supplies deltoid & teres minor.
  • Damage to this nerve results in loss of sensation at upper lateral part of arm known as “ Regimental badge anaesthesia”

 

 

  • In A option Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm is mentioned which is wrong.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.

 

  • Abduction of the shoulder:

 

 

  • Pyomyositis in the deltoid muscle would primarily affect the function of the deltoid, which is responsible for abduction.

 

Option C.

 

  • The deltoid muscle, particularly its anterior fibers, plays a role in flexing the arm at the shoulder.
  • Pyomyositis affecting the deltoid muscle could feasibly lead to weakness in flexing the arm at the shoulder joint, as the compromised muscle may lose strength and functionality.

 

Option D.

 

  • The primary muscles for extending the arm at the shoulder are the posterior deltoid, latissimus dorsi, and teres major.
  • Since the posterior belly of the deltoid muscle is involved in this case, it could lead to an inability or weakness in extending the arm at the shoulder joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sensation in the lower lateral aspect of the arm is generally mediated by the cutaneous nerves, which is branch of radial nerve.
  • Pyomyositis of the deltoid muscle primarily affects the muscle tissue and potentially the surrounding structures due to inflammation.
  • However, it is less likely to directly impact the axillary nerve & radial nerve unless there is a significant spread of infection or inflammation. Thus, a loss of sensation is not a typical complication of deltoid muscle pyomyositis.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh 3rd edition, pg. 89

choices.text: The shaft is triangular in the upper half & cylindrical in lower part in cross section
The shaft has 2 borders and three surfaces
Upper third of the lateral border forms the lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left arm. The patient reports falling off a ladder approximately two hours prior to the presentation. On radiological examination, everything was seen as normal as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true about the shaft of the pointed structure A in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The shaft has 3 borders & 3 surface

 

Option C:

 

  • The indicated radiological image is showing transverse section of arm & indicated structured marked A is showing the shaft of humerus.
  • The shaft of humerus presents 3 surfaces: Anteromedial, anterolateral & posterior surfaces.

 

 

  • Bony landmarks & attachment of humerus shown in image:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • The proximal or upper half of the humerus shaft does tend to have a more cylindrical cross-section whereas in the lower half, the humerus becomes more triangular.
  • This triangular shape is better suited for the hinge-type joint at the elbow and provides a more uniform surface for muscle attachments and the interlocking of bones at the elbow joint.

 

Option B.

 

  • This statement is not accurate. The shaft of the humerus typically has three borders (anterior, medial, and lateral) and three surfaces (anterolateral, anteromedial, and posterior).
  • These borders and surfaces serve as attachment sites for muscles and provide structural integrity.

 

Option D.

 

  • Intertubercular sulcus is also also known as bicipital groove. The lateral boundary of it is formed by the inferior extension of greater tubercle. 
  • The bicipital groove runs along the proximal end of the humerus and gives attachment to the tendon of the latissimus dorsi.
  • The lateral border runs from the back part of the greater tubercle to the lateral epicondyle, and separates the anterolateral surface from posterior surface.
  • Therefore, option D is incorrect because the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus is formed by the greater tubercle, not by the upper third of the lateral border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shaft has 3 borders and 3 surfaces.

 

  • 3 Borders: Anterior, Medial, and Lateral.
  • 3 Surfaces: Antero-lateral, Antero-medial, and Posterior.
  • Attachments of bicipital groove
  1. On Medial lip - teres Major
  2. On lateral lip - Pectoralis major
  3. On Floor - latissimus dorsi
  • Tendon of biceps brachii passes via the groove but is not attached with the groove.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh 3rd edition, pg. 9

choices.text: In Colles fracture, the distal fragment shifts posteriorly and downward carrying with it the styloid process
In smith’s fracture the distal fragment is displaced posteriorly and upward

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. She developed pain, tenderness and swelling over the dorsal aspect of her right wrist. She experienced difficulty in performing movements at the wrist. X-ray showed fracture of lower end of lateral bone of forearm. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Option D. None of the above- this is the correct option because both the statements (Option & B) are incorrect.

 

Explanation:

 

The type of dislocation is always ascertained by the displacement of distal fragment and not proximal, i.e., if the distal fragment has displaced anteriorly and proximal fragment has displaced posteriorly - the dislocation will be reffered to as anterior and vice versa.

 

Option A.

 

  • Colles Fracture is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with dorsal (posterior) displacement of distal fragment along with upwards pulling of distal fragment including the styloid process.
  • This is called dinner fork deformity. Because of this shortening the styloid process of radius and ulna are more or less in line with each other. So, therefore the statement given in Option A is incorrect.

 

Option B.

 

  • Smith’s fracture  is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with ventral (anterior) displacement of distal fragment including the styloid process.,
  • Smith’s fracture is a fracture of the distal end of the radius and occurs from a fall on the back of hand.
  • It is also called reverse Colles or Garden spade deformity. So, therefore the statement given in the option B is also incorrect.

 

 

Option C. Option C can’t be correct since Both A and B options are incorrect.
Since All the options (A,B,C) are incorrect - None of the above is the correct answer
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 861

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a laceration in the anterior region of his elbow following a biking accident. During surgical exploration of the wound, the surgeon notes a structure that has been partially transected. This structure is immediately superficial to a key anatomical structure in the cubital fossa, which the surgeon aims to protect. Which structure is most likely lying underneath the transected tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brachial Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • In this clinical case bicipital aponeurosis is partially transected.
  • Bicipital aponeurosis is the expanded tendon of biceps brachii that inserts into ulna. It lies over the brachial artery.

 

The bicipital aponeurosis is an expansion of the tendon of biceps brachii that extends medially to blend with the deep fascia covering the flexor muscles of the forearm. It lies superficial to the brachial artery (protecting it) and deep to the median cubital vein. This relationship is important clinically because the bicipital aponeurosis separates the median cubital vein (commonly used for venipuncture) from the brachial artery, thereby providing protection to the artery during venipuncture procedures.
 

The contents of the cubital fossa from medial to lateral are:

  1. Median nerve
  2. Brachial artery
  3. Bicipital aponeurosis
  4. Radial nerve (on a deeper plane)
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median Cubital Vein

 

  • It is superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis and is often used for venipuncture.
  • Median cubital vein connects the cephalic and basilic vein.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve:

 

  • The radial nerve does not typically lie directly under the bicipital aponeurosis.
  • Instead, it travels along the radial side of the forearm and is more lateral in the cubital fossa.

 

Option D. Anterior Interosseous Artery:

 

  • This artery is a branch of the ulnar artery and is not covered by the bicipital aponeurosis.
  • It runs on the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane of the forearm and is not located in the cubital fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contents of Cubital Fossa - Superficial and deep (With respect to bicipital aponeurosis)
Deep contents (From Medial to Lateral direction)

  1. Median nerve
  2. Brachial artery
  3. Bicipital aponeurosis
  4. Radial nerve (on a deeper plane)
     

 

Cubital Fossa & Brachial Artery:

 

  • The bicipital aponeurosis covers the brachial artery as it courses through the cubital fossa, helping to protect it from compression or injury.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 101

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • This is the clinical case of supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • Median nerve and brachial artery are involved in supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of median nerve.

 

 

  • Supra condylar deformity results in gun stock deformity:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals).
  •  It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements, but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion.
  • Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Damage to this nerve results in an inability to extend the fingers and the wrist (wrist drop), not an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option D. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half fingers and the associated palm area.
  • It does not play a significant role in motor control of the thumb, particularly in flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of the median nerve, innervates the flexor pollicis longus, the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus.
  •  Injury to this nerve leads to deficits in flexion of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, often assessed by the "pinch grip" test where the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign (forming a circle with the thumb and index finger).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram singh, pg. 165

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who is a cashier in the bank presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of fatigue, vague abdominal discomfort and bloody stools. Colonoscopy revealed a mass in the descending colon. Surgical removal of the mass requires proper ligation of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Mesenteric Artery

 

Option C: The hindgut structures such as left 1/3 of transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum and upper part of anal canal are supplied by branches of inferior mesenteric arteryInternal iliac artery supplies structures within the pelvis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The coeliac trunk is a major artery that supplies foregut derivatives- stomach, duodenum upto opening of common bile duct, liver, spleen, pancreas. It is not primarily involved in the blood supply to the colon, especially not the descending colon.

 

Option B. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supplies midgut derivatives- duodenum distal to the opening of common bile duct, jejunum, ileum, ascending colon, right 2/3 of transverse colon pancreas. While the SMA is a critical artery in gastrointestinal surgery, it is not the primary artery supplying the descending colon.

 

Option D. The internal iliac artery primarily supplies blood to the pelvic organs and the pelvic walls. It is not directly involved in the vascular supply to the descending colon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) supplies blood to the latter parts of the large intestine, including the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum.

  • For a surgical resection of a mass in the descending colon, ligation of the IMA is typically required to properly manage the blood supply to the area of the tumor.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No. 1088

questions.text: All are branches of Inferior Mesenteric Artery except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle Rectal

 

Option C:

 

  • The inferior mesenteric artery is a major artery in the abdomen that supplies blood to the large intestine. Middle rectal artery arises from anterior division of internal iliac artery passes within lateral ligaments of rectum to supply lower third of rectum.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Left colic artery arises from inferior mesenteric artery and divides into ascending and descending branch. It supplies the descending colon and part of the transverse colon.

 

Option B. Sigmoidal arteries are two to three in number, arise from inferior mesenteric arteries. The sigmoidal arteries, also known as sigmoid arteries, are branches of the inferior mesenteric artery. They supply the sigmoid colon.

 

Option D. The highest sigmoidal artery anastomoses with a descending branch of the left colic artery and lowest sigmoidal artery with superior rectal artery. The superior rectal artery is the terminal branch of the inferior mesenteric artery. It supplies the upper part of the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The middle rectal artery is typically a branch of the internal iliac artery, not the inferior mesenteric artery. It supplies the rectum, which makes this the correct answer as it is not a branch of the IMA.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol II, Abdomen Pg179

choices.text: Mcburney's Point is at the Junction of Medial 2/3 and Lateral 1/3 of a line which Extends from the Umbilicus to the Right Anterior Superior Iliac Spine
Inflammation of Appendix Pain is referred to Umbilicus along the Distribution of T9 Segment
In Appendicitis the Pain is often first felt in the Umbilical Region then later in the Right Iliac Area.
Submucosa of Appendix is studded with numerous Lymphoid Follicles

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was brought to ER with complaints of acute pain around the umbilicus, fever and vomiting. On examination the surgeon noted maximum tenderness over McBurney’s point. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inflammation of Appendix Pain is referred to Umbilicus along the Distribution of T9 Segment

 

Option B:

 

  • Inflammation of appendix pain is referred to the umbilicus along the distribution of the T9 segment: This statement is not true.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. McBurney's point is a clinically significant anatomical landmark located approximately one-third of the way along a line drawn from the umbilicus to the right Anterior Superior Iliac Spine (ASIS). It is commonly used as a reference point for assessing tenderness in cases of suspected appendicitis.

 

 

 

Option C. The sequence of pain progression in appendicitis often starts with periumbilical pain, followed by the migration of pain to the right iliac area as the inflammation worsens. This pattern is characteristic of appendicitis.

 

Option D. The appendix is a lymphoid-rich organ with a high concentration of lymphoid follicles in its submucosa. This feature is a part of its role in the immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Appendix Nerve Supply

 

 

 

  • In cases of appendicitis, pain typically begins around the umbilicus (periumbilical) and then migrates to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, where McBurney's point is located. The referred pain pattern is along the distribution of the T10 segment.

  • In appendicitis the pain is often first felt in the umbilical region then later in the right iliac area due to local peritonitis.

  • Submucosa of appendix is studded with numerous lymphoid follicles; enlargement of these lymph nodes can obstruct blood supply and lead to inflammation of appendix

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No. 1142

questions.text: A biopsy from the upper lobe of a patient with suspected fungal infection shows budding yeasts with surrounding clear spaces. Which staining technique is most suitable for visualizing these fungal organisms and their characteristic capsules?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)

 

Option D:

 

The PAS stain is a carbohydrate stain that is particularly useful for identifying fungi because it stains the polysaccharides in fungal cell walls a bright magenta color. This stain would be appropriate for visualizing the capsule of budding yeasts, such as Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alizarin red is used for staining calcium and is not specific for fungi.

 

Option B. Verhoeff dye is used for staining elastic fibers and is not suitable for fungi.

 

Option C. Manson’s trichrome is a stain primarily used for detecting parasites, not fungal capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PAS stain is ideal for highlighting fungal cell walls and capsules, which are rich in polysaccharides, thus aiding in the diagnosis of fungal infections.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p551, 2/e p575, Jagadish Chander 3/e p518

questions.text: Which type of electron microscopy is best suited for examining internal structures of a cell?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). 

 

Option B:

 

TEM is used to view thin sections of samples, allowing examination of internal cellular structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM): Incorrect. SEM is used for surface imaging.

 

Option C. Light Microscopy: Incorrect. While useful, it doesn't provide the same resolution for internal structures as TEM.

 

Option D. X-ray Crystallography: Incorrect. This is used for determining molecular structures, not cellular imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TEM is for viewing thin sections of samples, providing detailed insight into the internal cellular architecture. 
  • Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), is primarily used for surface imaging, 
  • X-ray Crystallography is used for molecular structure determination rather than cellular imaging.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

choices.text: Every strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces the diphtheria toxin.
The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.
The gene for diphtheria toxin production is plasmid-borne.
The diphtheria toxin inhibits cyclic AMP (cAMP) production.

questions.text: A microbiology resident is lecturing on Corynebacterium diphtheriae. She asks the residents which of the following statements regarding the bacterium and its toxin is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.

 

Option B:

 

The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron. The bacterium produces the toxin when iron levels are low, which is a regulatory mechanism to conserve iron for the bacterium's own use.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Not all strains produce the toxin; only those infected with a bacteriophage that carries the tox gene can produce the diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C: The diphtheria toxin gene (tox) is not plasmid-borne; it is carried by a lysogenic bacteriophage integrated into the bacterium's genome.

 

Option D: The diphtheria toxin does not inhibit cAMP production; it inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria Toxin (DT) - DT consists of two fragments: Fragment A (active unit) and B (binding unit). Fragment B binds to host cell receptors, facilitating entry of Fragment A. Fragment A is internalized into host cells, where it ADP ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF2). Inhibition of EF2 leads to irreversible inhibition of protein synthesis, resulting in cell death. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p244, 2/e p254, Ananthanarayan 10/e p240

choices.text: The numerical aperture of the objective lens
The colour of the light used for illumination.
The thickness of the specimen cover glass
The distance between the objective lens and the specimen

questions.text: The resolving power of a light microscope is NOT influenced by which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The colour of the light used for illumination.

 

Option B:

 

While the wavelength of the light (which is related to colour) does affect specimen, the specific color itself does not directly influence resolving power unless it is considered in terms of wavelength.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The numerical aperture of the objective lens: Incorrect. The numerical aperture is directly related to the resolving power; higher numerical apertures allow for greater resolution.

 

Option C. The thickness of the specimen cover glass: Incorrect. The thickness of the cover glass can affect the path of light and thereby influence the resolution to some extent.

 

Option D. The distance between the objective lens and the specimen: Incorrect. The working distance can affect resolution, especially if it deviates significantly from the optimal focal length for which the objective lens is designed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resolving power of a light microscope is influenced by numerical aperture of the objective lens, thickness of the specimen and distance between the objective lens and the specimen, But not the color of light.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 08/4e

questions.text: A 25-year-old man, who recently returned from a trip to Africa where he swam in freshwater lakes, presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hematuria. His symptoms are suggestive of an infection acquired through water contact. Identifying the parasite whose infective form is cercariae is important for his diagnosis and treatment:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schistosoma haematobium

 

Option A:

 

Schistosoma haematobium's infective form is cercariae, which are released by freshwater snails and can penetrate human skin during contact with contaminated water. The patient's symptoms and exposure history are consistent with schistosomiasis, a disease caused by Schistosoma haematobium.

 

Life cycle

 

 

 

Figure: S. haematobium

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Paragonimus westermani: The infective form is metacercariae, not cercariae.

 

Option C) Fasciola hepatica: Also has metacercariae as the infective form.

 

Option D) Taenia solium: The infective form is the cysticercus, not cercariae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schistosoma haematobium - infective form is cercariae.
  • Paragonimus westermani and Fasciola hepatica - Metacercariae as their infective form, 
  • Taenia solium's - infective form is the cysticercus

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p194, 2/e p155

choices.text: Light source with a specific wavelength

questions.text: During a laboratory class, medical students are shown an image of bacteria exhibiting green fluorescence. The instructor explains that a specific component of the microscope is critical for visualizing this type of image. Which component is essential in a microscope to observe fluorescently labeled specimens?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dichroic mirror

 

Option D:

 

The dichroic mirror is crucial in fluorescence microscopy as it reflects the specific wavelength of light used to excite the fluorescent dye and transmits the emitted fluorescence from the sample, enabling the capture of such images.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluorescence filter set: Incorrect. While essential for selecting the specific wavelengths of light, the filter set alone is not responsible for the generation of the fluorescent signal.

 

Option B. Light source with a specific wavelength: Incorrect. A specific wavelength light source excites the fluorophores, but it's the dichroic mirror that differentiates the emission from excitation light.

 

Option C. Fluorescence objective lens: Incorrect. The objective lens focuses the light on the sample and collects the emitted light, but it does not distinguish between the excitation and emission wavelengths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dichroic mirror as an essential component of fluorescence microscopy that separates the excitation light from the emitted fluorescence, allowing for the visualization of fluorescently labeled specimens.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 09/4e

questions.text: For standardizing an antibiotic sensitivity test, the turbidity of the bacterial suspension should be adjusted to which McFarland standard?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McFarland 0.5 standard

 

Option A:

 

The McFarland 0.5 standard is commonly used as a reference for adjusting the turbidity of bacterial suspensions to approximate a standard number of bacteria for antibiotic susceptibility testing.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. McFarland 1.5 standard: This standard would indicate a denser suspension than typically used for antibiotic sensitivity tests.

 

Option C. McFarland 2.0 standard: A McFarland 2.0 standard is too turbid and would lead to inaccuracies in interpreting antibiotic sensitivity.

 

Option D. McFarland 0.75 standard: While closer to the correct answer, this is not a standard commonly used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McFarland standards are used as a reference to adjust the turbidity of bacterial suspensions so that the number of bacteria will be within a given range.

 

  • A 0.5 McFarland standard is prepared by mixing 0.05 mL of barium chloride dihydrate with 9.95 mL of 1% sulfuric acid and its equivalent to 150 million no. of bacteria/mL in a broth.
  • For antibiotic sensitivity test, the organism broth prepared should match with- 0.5 McFarland standard.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 41/4e

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents to the clinic with a recent history of fever, lethargy, and a lacy, reticular rash on the body. The mother reports that the child had a "slapped cheek" appearance a few days ago. The child has a known history of sickle cell disease. Which of the following complications is most likely to develop in this patient due to the current infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aplastic crisis

 

Option A:

 

Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells, which can lead to a transient arrest in red blood cell production. This is particularly significant in patients with conditions that already compromise red blood cell lifespan, such as sickle cell disease. The result is an aplastic crisis, a rapid drop in hemoglobin levels due to the combination of shortened red blood cell lifespan and a halt in production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Acute hemolytic anemia: While patients with sickle cell disease are at risk for hemolytic anemia, it is not specifically associated with parvovirus B19 infection.

 

Option C. Sepsis : There is no indication of a bacterial infection leading to sepsis in the clinical scenario provided.

 

Option D. Splenic sequestration crisis: This is a complication of sickle cell disease where red blood cells pool in the spleen, leading to a sudden drop in hemoglobin. It is not directly related to parvovirus B19 infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, known to specifically target erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. This viral infection can lead to a transient arrest in red blood cell production. In patients with sickle cell disease, where red blood cell lifespan is already compromised, this can precipitate an aplastic crisis.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p464

questions.text: A 55-year-old individual living in a tropical region presents with complaints of eye discomfort, including itching and redness. On examination, small subcutaneous nodules are observed under the skin. The patient is concerned about the eye symptoms and asks if these nodules could be related. Which of the following parasites does NOT cause lymphatic filariasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loa loa

 

Option A:

 

Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, causes subcutaneous nodules and eye symptoms but does not cause lymphatic filariasis. It is important to differentiate between different filarial worms when assessing clinical symptoms.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Wuchereria bancrofti - Wuchereria bancrofti is a known cause of lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option C) Brugia malayi - Brugia malayi is another filarial worm that can cause lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D) Brugia timori - Brugia timori is also a filarial worm associated with lymphatic filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wuchereria bancrofti (MC), Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori are all known to cause lymphatic filariasis. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p263, 2/e p221

choices.text: Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar
Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar
Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium
Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

 

Option C:

 

Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium: Correct. H. influenzae grows on chocolate agar, which provides the X and V factors released from lysed blood cells. It can also grow on blood agar if Staphylococcus species are present (satellitism), which provide the necessary V factor. It does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar: H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar as it is a selective medium designed for Gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae has specific growth requirements not met by this medium.

 

Option B. Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar: Similar to option A, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar. It can grow on chocolate agar because it provides the necessary factors (X factor - hemin and V factor - NAD) released from lysed blood cells.

 

Option D. Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar: As previously explained, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Haemophilus influenzae grows on chocolate agar and can grow on blood agar under specific conditions (presence of Staphylococcus species for V factor), but it does not grow on MacConkey agar due to its selective nature against non-coliform bacteria.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 2/e p361

choices.text: To maintain the integrity and quality of the images produced
To avoid damaging the vacuum system

questions.text: A laboratory technician is preparing biological samples for observation under an electron microscope. Before placing the samples in the microscope, they must undergo a critical preparatory step that involves dehydration. A medical student observing the process inquiries about the purpose of this step. In electron microscopy, why must samples be dehydrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To maintain the integrity and quality of the images produced.

 

Option B:

 

Electron microscopy requires that samples be placed in a vacuum because air molecules would scatter the electrons and degrade the quality of the image. If biological samples contain water, the water can vaporize in the vacuum, introducing vapor molecules that would interfere with the electron beam. Therefore, samples are dehydrated to prevent these issues and to preserve the structure of the samples, allowing for high-resolution imaging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. To increase their size: Dehydration does not purposefully increase sample size.

 

Option C. To avoid damaging the vacuum system While causing damage to the vacuum system is a concern, it's not the primary reason for dehydration.

 

Option D. To enhance color contrast: Incorrect. Electron microscopy images are not in color, and dehydration does not affect contrast in this way.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Dehydration of samples in electron microscopy is crucial to preserve the structure of the samples, allowing for high-resolution imaging.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

choices.text: Antigen is presented via MHC–I complexes
APCs are required before a response to viruses are generated
Direct antibody stimulation still requires APC’s
Antigen processed by APC are recognized by CD 4+ T Cells

questions.text: Researchers are developing a new agent to enhance the recognition of foreign antigens by antigen-presenting cells (APCs). As part of their research, they are reviewing the physiological aspects of APCs. Which of the following statements is true regarding the functions of APCs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antigen processed by APC are recognized by CD 4+ T Cells

 

Option D:

 

Antigen-presenting cells process antigens and present them on their surface via MHC II molecules to CD4+ T cells. Exogenous (foreign) antigens are first phagocytosed by APCs, then they are processed by APCs and presented on the surface of APCs along with MHC II to be recognized by CD 4+ T Cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antigen is presented via MHC–I complexes: This is more characteristic of cells presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells.

 

Option B. APCs are required before a response to viruses are generated: While true, APCs are not exclusively required for viral responses.

 

Option C. Direct antibody stimulation still requires APC’s: B cells can be directly stimulated by antigens without APCs in some cases.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Antigens processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) are indeed recognized by CD4+ T cells. This recognition is a key step in the immune response:

 

Role of APCs: APCs, like dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells, process exogenous (foreign) antigens and present them on their surface bound to MHC II molecules.

 

Interaction with CD4+ T Cells: These MHC II-antigen complexes on APCs are recognized by CD4+ T cells. The interaction is crucial for the activation and differentiation of CD4+ T cells, leading to various immune responses, including helper functions for other immune cells.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p162, 2/e p170

choices.text: Antibody to anti- Ca receptor
Blockage of nerve conduction through myoneural junction

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. Based on her symptoms, which of the following is true about Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Antibody to Ach (Acetylcholine) receptor

 

Option A:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by the presence of antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission and muscle weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Antibody to anti- Ca receptor: Not associated with Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Option C. Ach is not secreted: Acetylcholine is secreted but its action is impaired due to antibody binding.

 

Option D. Blockage of nerve conduction: The primary issue is at the neuromuscular junction, not nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathophysiology of Myasthenia Gravis - involves antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology, 2/e p191

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing data from a community screening program for Hepatitis B virus (HBV). Which of the following serological markers is most useful as an epidemiological marker to determine the rate of HBV infection in the community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

Option A:

 

Serological marker used to identify current infection with Hepatitis B virus and, when used in epidemiological studies, reflects the prevalence of the virus within a community.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HBeAg - Indicates active replication and high infectivity, but not used primarily for epidemiological screening.

 

Option C. Anti-HBe - Suggests lower levels of viral replication, but its absence does not rule out infection.

 

Option D. Anti-HBs - Indicates immunity to HBV from past infection or vaccination, not current infection rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidemiological marker in HBV infection: HbsAg and Anti- HBc IgG for assessing the prevalence of HBV infection in a population during community health screenings.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534-35, 2/e p557-558, Park 24/e p230, 23/e p210-20

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a high fever, weight loss, and a localized abscess on his leg. He has recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a complex abscess with possible involvement of the underlying bone. A sample of the abscess fluid is sent for culture. Which organism is most commonly associated with abscess formation in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

Option B:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei is the causative agent of melioidosis, which is endemic in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. It is a gram-negative bacillus found in soil and water and can infect humans through inoculation from a contaminated source. Melioidosis often presents with abscess formation and can involve multiple organs, including the skin and bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burkholderia mallei: Causes glanders, which is primarily a disease of animals such as horses, and human infections are rare.

 

Option C. Burkholderia cepacia: Mainly associated with respiratory infections in patients with cystic fibrosis, not typically known for causing abscesses in travelers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei as the causative organism of melioidosis, commonly presenting with abscesses and commonly contracted in Southeast Asia.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p342, 2/e p355, Ananthanarayan 9/e p317, 18, 10/e p323-324

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman from Chennai with a CD4 count of 50 cells/mm³ presents with a dry cough and dyspnea. A chest CT scan shows ground-glass opacities. Bronchoalveolar lavage is performed. What is the drug of choice for the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotrimoxazole

 

Option A:

 

The patient's symptoms and CD4 count are suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), for which cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Penicillin: This antibiotic is used against bacterial infections and has no activity against fungi like Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: While amphotericin B is an antifungal agent, it is not the first-line treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It may be used in severe cases or when patients cannot tolerate cotrimoxazole.

 

Option D. Clotrimazole: This is an antifungal medication commonly used for treating fungal infections of the skin, mouth, and vagina, not for systemic infections like Pneumocystis pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in an HIV/AIDS patient with severe immunosuppression - cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line treatment.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 576, 2/e p601

choices.text: Monoecious, and the organism is related to parthenogenesis.
Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water.
Pulmonary pneumonia is caused by the same organism.
The body acquires this infection through filariform larvae.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of kidney transplantation presents with persistent diarrhea. He mentions recent gardening without gloves, which he has taken up since his retirement. A picture accompanying his case shows active worms in his stool. 

 

 

Considering the worm motility observed and his immunocompromised status, which of the following is the correct statement about the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The body acquires this infection through filariform larvae.

 

Option D:


The clinical presentation of diarrhea and the history of kidney transplantation, which implies immunosuppression, along with the observation of active worms in the stool, is indicative of an infection by Strongyloides stercoralis. This organism has a life cycle that includes the penetration of the host skin by filariform larvae, which is a common mode of entry, especially in individuals who have soil contact without proper protection. In immunocompromised patients, this can lead to hyperinfection and potentially lethal dissemination.

 

Larva in stool specimen of a transplant patient with diarrhoea suggestive of larva of Strongyloides

 

  • Strongyloides is dioecious, but exhibits parthenogenesis.

  •  Transmitted by skin penetration of through filariform larvae, not by intake contaminated food and water

  •  Loffler’s pneumonia is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Monoecious organisms and parthenogenesis do not accurately describe Strongyloides, which is dioecious and reproduces through autoinfection.
 

Option B. While Strongyloides can be transmitted through contaminated soil, transmission through food and water is more characteristic of other organisms like Giardia or Cryptosporidium.
 

Option C. Pulmonary pneumonia is typically associated with other orgnasims.  Strongyloides stercoralis. Can be associated with Loeffler’s pneumonia when the worm passes through the lung to complete its cycle

 

Educational Objective:
 

Hyperinfection syndrome: Autoinfection is responsible for maintaining the infection as long as 30–40 years and can cause disseminated infection and hyperinfection syndrome. The underlying cause of hyperinfection syndrome is the repeated autoinfection cycles, which leads to generation of large number of filariform larvae. The larvae penetrate the GIT and migrate to various organs.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e p190

choices.text: Add on metronidazole to the current regimen

questions.text: A patient with a history of ESBL-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia is currently on ceftriaxone and amikacin. Following treatment, the patient's clinical condition has not improved. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Switch to a carbapenem antibiotic 

 

Option C:

 

Carbapenems are the treatment of choice for serious infections caused by ESBL-producing organisms due to their resistance to hydrolysis by ESBL enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Escalate ceftriaxone dosage: Increasing the dose of ceftriaxone is unlikely to be effective against an ESBL-producing organism.

 

Option B. Add on metronidazole to the current regimen: Metronidazole is primarily used for anaerobic coverage and would not be appropriate for ESBL-producing Klebsiella.

 

Option D. Discontinue amikacin and start vancomycin: Vancomycin is not effective against Gram-negative bacteria like Klebsiella pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbapenems are preferred due to their resistance to hydrolysis by ESBL enzymes, making them effective against ESBL-producing organisms. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 65/4e

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the clinic with signs of weakness and pallor. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 4.8 g/dL. The child's parents report a history of tarry stools. The family lives in a rural area with poor sanitation. Physical examination shows no significant findings except for pallor. Which parasite is most likely responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hookworm

 

Option A:

 

Hookworm infection is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia, especially in children living in areas with poor sanitation. The larvae of hookworms penetrate the skin and eventually reach the intestines, where they attach to the mucosa, causing chronic blood loss leading to iron deficiency anemia. The child's presentation with weakness, severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL), and history of tarry stools (indicative of gastrointestinal blood loss) align with the clinical manifestation of hookworm infection.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Roundworm: Typically causes intestinal obstruction or malabsorption but not significant blood loss.

 

Option C. Whipworm: Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) can cause dysentery and rectal prolapse but is less likely to cause severe anemia.
